abstracts.cdata!:
The loan for the SN Metal Technical
            Assistance Project for Algeria was approved on November 13,
            1979 but never signed, because the Borrower withdrew the
            loan application. As a result, none of the objectives of the
            project were met and the project outcome is rated as
            unsatisfactory. At the time of approval, every indication
            was that the contract would be formally signed at once and
            implementation would start immediately. Soon thereafter,
            however, disagreement arose between SN Metal and UEC (a
            subsidiary of US Steel) on accommodation for the technical
            assistance team. Despite several efforts on the part of the
            Bank team to facilitate agreement, SN Metal and UEC could
            not reconcile their differences. Subsequently, the Bank
            learned that the Algerian Government was no longer fully
            committed to the concept of large scale technical assistance
            on which this project was based. As the loan and guarantee
            agreements had not been signed, no formal action was
            required on the part of the Bank.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project consists of a program of
            technical assistance to SN Metal to strengthen the
            company's overall effectiveness through the attainment
            of three basic objectives: Part A full capacity operation at
            SN Metal's new production units, Oran III and Annaba
            II, through appropriate start-up and operating assistance;
            Part B evaluation of SN Metal's medium- and long-term
            investment program to establish priorities and prepare
            feasibility studies for two high-priority projects; and Part
            C elaboration of a master plan for SN Metal to determine its
            proper role in the Algerian economy, define its appropriate
            overall organization and, in particular, to allocate
            production among its units manufacturing structural steel
            work, plate work and mechanical equipment in an optimal
            fashion. The program, which will take about four years,
            involves some 2,900 man-months of technical assistance at an
            average foreign exchange cost per man-month of $8,700 in
            1979 prices, plus about $2,900 per man-month for local
            subsistence. The Bank loan would finance a first phase of
            the program only. Risks relate to the complexity of the
            tasks involved, problems of logistics and the human factor,
            which is to considerable importance to the successful
            execution of technical assistance.
